Rule3: Here is an important piece of information about the finch: if it works fewer hours than before then it does not take over the emperor of the lizard for sure. Rule4: If the peafowl has more money than the seal and the duck combined, then the peafowl hides the cards that she has from the finch. Rule5: If the peafowl hides her cards from the finch, then the finch is not going to borrow a weapon from the german shepherd. Rule6: The finch unquestionably takes over the emperor of the lizard, in the case where the liger borrows a weapon from the finch.
preferences: Rule1 is preferred over Rule2. Rule1 is preferred over Rule4. Rule6 is preferred over Rule3.
example: A few players are playing a boardgame. The current state of the game is as follows. The duck has 38 dollars. The finch is named Buddy. The finch reduced her work hours recently. The frog is named Chickpea. The liger borrows one of the weapons of the finch. The peafowl has 95 dollars, and does not surrender to the llama. The peafowl has one friend. The seal has 56 dollars. And the rules of the game are as follows. Rule1: Be careful when something does not build a power plant near the green fields of the owl and also does not surrender to the llama because in this case it will surely not hide the cards that she has from the finch (this may or may not be problematic). Rule2: Regarding the peafowl, if it has more than two friends, then we can conclude that it hides the cards that she has from the finch. Rule3: Here is an important piece of information about the finch: if it works fewer hours than before then it does not take over the emperor of the lizard for sure. Rule4: If the peafowl has more money than the seal and the duck combined, then the peafowl hides the cards that she has from the finch. Rule5: If the peafowl hides her cards from the finch, then the finch is not going to borrow a weapon from the german shepherd. Rule6: The finch unquestionably takes over the emperor of the lizard, in the case where the liger borrows a weapon from the finch. Rule1 is preferred over Rule2. Rule1 is preferred over Rule4. Rule6 is preferred over Rule3. Based on the game state and the rules and preferences, does the finch borrow one of the weapons of the german shepherd?
proof: We know the peafowl has 95 dollars, the seal has 56 dollars and the duck has 38 dollars, 95 is more than 56+38=94 which is the total money of the seal and duck combined, and according to Rule4 "if the peafowl has more money than the seal and the duck combined, then the peafowl hides the cards that she has from the finch", and for the conflicting and higher priority rule Rule1 we cannot prove the antecedent "the peafowl does not build a power plant near the green fields of the owl", so we can conclude "the peafowl hides the cards that she has from the finch". We know the peafowl hides the cards that she has from the finch, and according to Rule5 "if the peafowl hides the cards that she has from the finch, then the finch does not borrow one of the weapons of the german shepherd", so we can conclude "the finch does not borrow one of the weapons of the german shepherd". So the statement "the finch borrows one of the weapons of the german shepherd" is disproved and the answer is "no".
theory:
Facts:
	(duck, has, 38 dollars)
	(finch, is named, Buddy)
	(finch, reduced, her work hours recently)
	(frog, is named, Chickpea)
	(liger, borrow, finch)
	(peafowl, has, 95 dollars)
	(peafowl, has, one friend)
	(seal, has, 56 dollars)
	~(peafowl, surrender, llama)
Rules:
	Rule1: ~(X, build, owl)^~(X, surrender, llama) => ~(X, hide, finch)
	Rule2: (peafowl, has, more than two friends) => (peafowl, hide, finch)
	Rule3: (finch, works, fewer hours than before) => ~(finch, take, lizard)
	Rule4: (peafowl, has, more money than the seal and the duck combined) => (peafowl, hide, finch)
	Rule5: (peafowl, hide, finch) => ~(finch, borrow, german shepherd)
	Rule6: (liger, borrow, finch) => (finch, take, lizard)
Preferences:
	Rule1 > Rule2
	Rule1 > Rule4
	Rule6 > Rule3
label: disproved
